moves: 1. d4 d5 2. Nf3 c5 3. e3 Nc6 4. b3 e6 5. Bb2 Nf6 6. Nbd2 cxd4 7. exd4
comment:
From "My Chess Career", I report Capablanca's comment: << ... I remember I
played 1.d4 because that way Corzo could not take too much advantage from my
weakness in the opening.>>

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. Nf3 c5 3. e3 Nc6 4. b3 e6 5. Bb2 Nf6 6. Nbd2 cxd4 7. exd4 Bd6 8. Bd3 O-O 9. O-O Nh5 10. g3 f5 11. Ne5 Nf6 12. f4 Bxe5 13. fxe5 Ng4 14. Qe2 Qb6 15. Nf3 Bd7 16. a3

1. d4 d5 2. Nf3 c5 3. e3 Nc6 4. b3 e6 5. Bb2 Nf6 6. Nbd2 cxd4 7. exd4 Bd6 8. Bd3 O-O 9. O-O Nh5 10. g3 f5 11. Ne5 Nf6 12. f4 Bxe5 13. fxe5 Ng4 14. Qe2 Qb6 15. Nf3 Bd7 16. a3 Kh8 17. h3 Nh6 18. Qf2 Nf7 19. Kg2 g5 20. g4 Ne7 21. Qe3 Rg8 22. Rae1 Ng6 23. gxf5 Nf4+ 24. Kh2 Nxd3 25. Qxd3
comment:
For the Master, one of the most difficult task is to build a position which
allows him to switch to the attack. Probably today I would have done better,
but - after all I did not play badly and indeed I invented a rather brilliant
combination. (Capablanca)

comment: Almost certainly today I would have played

Rxf1 Rxf7 34. Rxf5 Rxf5 35. Nxf5+ Kh7 36. Ne7
comment:
Capablanca's skill is
remarkable. At 12 years he already user the "Knight+Bishop barrier" to
imprison the enemy King (with the last move g8, g7, g6 are inhibited to Kh7).

Rxf1 Rxf7 34. Rxf5 Rxf5 35. Nxf5+ Kh7 36. Ne7 Rf8 37. Kg2 h5 38. d6 g4 39. hxg4 hxg4 40. Be5 Kh6 41. d7 Rd8 42. Ng8+ Rxg8 43. Bf6 Kg6 44. d8=Q Rxd8 45. Bxd8 b5 46. Kf2 Kf5 47. Ke3 Ke5 48. Kd3 Kd5 49. Kc3 g3 50. Bh4 g2 51. Bf2 a5 52. b4 Ke5
comment:
Cunningly Black expects bxa5? which would draw because the promoting square a8
is white and ... "we all" know that White cannot win anymore afterKe5-d6-c6-b7-
a8 leaving the Pb5 too to the greedy opponent. White, instead, wins easily by
keeping the pawn on the b file.

The "limit" (the Pb5 rank) is crossed, and with it the last
defense.... or maybe the next to the last, as we shall see.
